title-group.article-title: A new method of measuring the bending rigidity of fabrics and its application to the determination of the their anisotropy

abstract.p: Bending rigidity is a significant property of textiles that influences their further behavior, for example draping and wrinkling. The thorough analysis of draping and wrinkling behavior of textiles requires also knowledge of bending rigidity of the textiles in different directions, the so-called anisotropy of bending rigidity. Anisotropy of bending rigidity has been so far mostly measured on rectangular shaped samples; nevertheless, the circular shape seems to be the ideal one. This article presents device TH-7, which enables one to measure this non-standard circular shaped sample. Comparing the results of measuring of bending rigidity on the standard device KES-FB2 with the results of measuring on device TH-7, we can see a very good correspondence, that is, the value of the correlation coefficient equals 0.9. The described way of measuring the anisotropy of bending rigidity on circular samples will speed up and improve the quality of further research in the field of influence of the textile structure (weave, sett) on bending rigidity and, consequently, on draping and wrinkling of the textile.

body.p: The aesthetic appearance of garments is particularly influenced by two properties: draping and wrinkling. Both these properties characterize the behavior of the textile in space. The deformation of the textile in space is also influenced by the anisotropy of bending rigidity, which is the value of bending rigidity measured in different directions. Problems of the anisotropy of bending rigidity and its influence on other properties (particularly draping and wrinkling) are studied in the works of the following researchers: Hedfi et al.,1 Hemilton and Postle,2 Hu et al.,3 Omeroglu et al.,4 Shinohara,5 Sidabraite and Masteikaitė,6 Yu et al.,7 Niwa and Seto,8 Sun,9 Fridrichová,10 and Fridrichová et al.11 The structure of textiles (weave, sett, yarn fineness) also contributes to the anisotropic behavior of bending rigidity. The works of Alima et al.,12 Fridrichová and Tunák,13 Lee,14 Shinohara et al.15 and Yu and Du16 focus on these problems.

Finding out the anisotropy of bending rigidity has been so far carried out on rectangular shaped formulas, or on square shaped ones. The first sample was cut in the direction of warp threads and every following one was turned by relevant degrees in relation to the warp. A large amount of material was then necessary for the preparation of samples. The circular shape of the sample seems to be the ideal one for finding out the anisotropy of bending rigidity. Bending rigidity can be measured in many different directions on just one sample. By using the circular shape for a sample, a significant amount of material, as well as time, can be saved.

The topic of this article is the description of a device and a new method of measuring. A new device, TH-7, is described on which the bending rigidity of circular samples, and also of square and rectangle ones, can be measured. The device came into existence by innovation of the device TH-5. The innovation was described by the authors Naujokaitytě et al.17 and Ozcelik et al.18; nevertheless, here we are presenting the information about the final form of the device TH-7, which originated on the basis of further modifications in the year 2011.

The article contains not only the description of the device, but also the experiments by means of which correctness of the measured data on device TH-7 was proved. The experiments were carried out on two devices for a set of five types of fabrics. The final values of bending rigidity measured on devices TH-7 and KES-FB2 were compared using regress analysis. The correlation coefficient reached a value of 0.9.
The article describes and analyses the factors that have impact on the measured values on device TH-7. Among the factors are clamping of the sample and the shape of the bent sample in the jaw.

The measurements were also evaluated from the point of view of repeatability and reproducibility. There are described experiments that led to the verification of the correctness of the method of measuring the anisotropy of bending rigidity on circular samples. The anisotropy of bending rigidity was, in the first experiment, measured as usual, that is, on rectangular or square samples. The square samples were cut so that every following one was turned by 22.5° in relation to the preceding sample. Then the samples were measured on devices TH-7 and KES-FB2. The resulting values were compared using regress analysis. The result of the correlation analysis for square samples equaled a value of 0.97. Afterwards, circular samples were cut and measured on device TH-7. The results of bending rigidity measured on square and circular samples were tested using regress analysis. The value of the correlation coefficient was 0.99.
Finally, the article contains description of possibilities of how to use the newly designed method of measuring bending rigidity on circular samples.

sec.title: Description of device and method of measuring
sec.p:
The device TH-7 (Figure 1) was developed by means of innovation of device TH-5 on which only rectangle samples sized 2.5 cm × 5 cm could be measured. Figure 1.
Device TH-7.

In the following items we are giving differences between the model of device TH-5 and TH-7 or, rather, we are presenting the essential innovations that were realized on the older device TH-5.
The clamping and sensor jaw was extended so that the device could be used for measuring rectangular, square and circular samples.
The revolving clamping jaw was designed so that it could turn in both directions, which enabled one to draw the whole hysteresis loop of bending (Figure 2).
The sensor jaw was adjusted so that the bending power could be scanned in both directions: face–face and back–back. The sensor jaw is U-shaped.
There are Teflon tubes on the sensor jaw that reduce the coefficient of friction between the tube and the bent fabric.
To control the device and store the measured data, new software was developed. The output of the measuring is a hysteresis loop (curve). The data are stored in a data file (csv) and at the same time in a graphic file (png), as shown in Figure 2.
Device TH-7 also enables one to measure the cyclical strain of the sample. It is possible to set 10 cycles of automatic bending at maximum. The values of every cycle are recorded, as well as the final average value.
Figure 2.
Hysteresis loop of bending from device TH-7.

The device enables the measuring of non-textile materials, for example paper, foils and membranes; however, it was constructed mainly for measuring fabrics. It has three ranges of measured bending force.

The range of measuring force of bending is from 40 to 4000 mN. The output from the device is the value of bending force Fm [mN]. This value can be measured for various sample widths, with 50 mm being the maximum and the minimum being unlimited. The suggested length of the sample is 50 mm; however, textiles of 25 mm minimum length can be measured, too. Materials whose thickness does not exceed 1.5 mm can be bent. The distance between the clamping and the sensor jaws is 14 mm. The scheme and photography of bending the fabric on device TH-7 is given in Figure 3. Figure 3.
Scheme and photography of bending sample on device TH-7. Cj: clamping jaw; Sj: sensor jaw, it is scanning bending force (Fm = Fh horizontal force component); Fr: resultant force; Fv: vertical force. (a) Sample in zero position. (b) Sample turned to position +90° face–face. (c) Sample turned to position −90° back–back.

The output value from device TH-5 or TH-7 is bending force Fm. The calculation of bending moment Mo [Nm] is described for the older model, device TH-5, according to the standard ČSN 80 0858, where Mo = Fm × k, k = 0.604 for samples of 2.5 cm width. There is more information in the article by Naujokaitytě et al.17

If we want to compare the mutual bending behavior of textiles that were measured only on device TH-7, it is possible to work only with the value of bending force Fm [Nm], so it is not necessary to convert Fm to the value of bending rigidity B [Nm2/m], or to the bending moment M [Nm]. Nevertheless, for the other cases it is possible to convert bending force Fm by means of a constant to bending rigidity B [Nm2/m], as shown in the following part of the article.

sec.title: Bending moment value on device KES-FB2 and device TH-7
sec.p:
For device KES-FB2 the sample is loaded by pure bending, that is, the same amount of bending moment affects both sides of the sample, while the curvature of the circular arc is 1/r. Device TH-7 is constructed so that the highest value of the bending moment acted at the point where the sample is clamped; however, at the point of the sensor jaw the value of the bending moment equals zero. The shape of curvature of the fabric when bent on device TH-7 remains the same for all values of measured bending rigidity. The curvature is non-constant (see Figure 4). Figure 4.
Scheme of bending moment on devices TH-7 and KES-FB-2. Fm: measured force; Fc: calculated force.

The constant shape of the bending curvature on device TH-7 was proved both by calculation of the discrete model according to Figure 5 and by the experiment. The bending curves were photographed and converted into a coordinate system and the mutual differences were compared. Figure 5.
Discrete model of bending curve.

The shape of the bending curve of the tested sample, with high bending rigidity (measured force F = 40.9 × 10–3 N), was identical to the shape of the bending curve of the fabric whose bending rigidity was approximately 10 times lower (measured force F = 4.9 × 10–3 N).
The variation coefficient of the observed points of bending curves ranged between 1 and 15%. The shape of the curvature is influenced by gravity.

As has already been said above, if we want to compare the values of bending force Fm [mN] gained on device TH-7 with values of bending rigidity B [Nm2/m] gained on device KES-FB2, then the measured bending force Fm has to be multiplied by the constant. To determine the constant, a simple discrete model of continuous bending curve with irregular curvature was developed (Figure 5).

The non-linear model for large deformations proceeds from the work published by Mevald and Fridrichová,19 where the continuous bending curve is calculated for device TH-5, where the angle of turning the jaw equals 60°. For device TH-7, the angle of turning the jaw equals 90°, to which the adjusted discrete model of bending curve corresponds (see Figure 5).

By means of iterative solution of a system of non-linear equations, it is possible to determine the total length L=∑i=1 nli of the bending curve of approximated sections n of length li for the given distance h, measured by the horizontal section of bending force Fm = F. cosβ, where F is the total force and the angle of the last section of length is ln. Further, it is possible to determine bending rigidity Bs for sample width s or, rather, the bending rigidity of unit width B = Bs/s. For the same length of sections li = l = L/n and given values xn = 0, yn = h.

β = ψn – π/2, ψo = 0, xo = 0, yo = 0 at the beginning of the iterative process; we choose the convenient ϕi > 0. The algorithm of calculation proceeds from the relations: ψi=ψi-1+ϕi, xi=xi-1+l·cosψ, yi=yi-1+l·sinψ, Mi=F [cosβ (yn-yi-1 )+sinβ(xi-1) ], ϕi=Miki,k1=2.Bsl,k2,k3,…,kn=Bsl.

For the iterative solution, we used solver Given-Find in the program surrounding MathCad 14 and we got the approximate course of the bending line from the calculation results. From the bending rigidity of the textile B = Bs/s [Nm2/m], related to unit width s, we will determine the constant.

From the given relation we will obtain the constant = 0.0334, which expresses the correction of curvature or, rather, the influence of the variable moment during bending the sample, as seen in Figure 5: κ=BF1·cosβ=BsF·cosβ [m2 ] whereF1=Fs [Nm ],Fm=F·cosβ, thenB=κ·F·cosβs=κ·Fms [N23m2m ]

sec.title: Overhang of sample behind the sensor jaw
sec.p:
The sample on device TH-7 is clamped only into one jaw (see Figure 6), while the other end goes through the sensor jaw. This is why it is important in all measurements to keep the length of the overhang of the sample behind the sensor jaw. This length has an impact on the output value of measuring the bending force, as shown in Figure 7. Figure 6.
Scheme of clamped fabric. Cj: clamping jaw; Sj: sensor jaw; yc = 14 mm (distance between jaws Cj and Sj); yo: length of overhang of sample behind the sensor jaw.
Figure 7.
Influence of overhang part of sample on bending force.

Figure 8 illustrates the scheme of clamping samples on device TH-7 and the overhang of the sample behind the sensor jaw. The recommended sample length behind sensor jaw yo is 10 mm (see Figure 8(b)). Figure 8.
Various lengths of clamping in device TH-7, where (a) yo = 5 mm, (b) yo = 10 mm, (c) yo = 25 mm.

Figure 7 illustrates the influence of the change of the measured force Fm depending on the change of the length of overhang of the sample behind the sensor jaw yo. For measuring textiles of minimum length of overhang yo = 5 mm, we will obtain bending force Fma = 5.6 mN (Figure 7, point a). For the recommended value of overhang yo = 10 mm, we will obtain value Fmb = 5.7 mN (Figure 7, point b). The difference between these two bending forces is only 2%. However, if the overhang length is yo = 25 mm, we will measure bending force value Fmc = 7.5 mN (Figure 7, point c). However, the difference between Fmb and Fmc is 15%. For measuring on device TH-7, it is necessary to keep the same, or rather the recommended length of overhang of the sample, behind the sensor jaw.

sec.title: Comparison of values of bending rigidity measured on devices KES-FB2 and TH-7
sec.p:
Five kinds of textiles were used for the experiment. They were raw materials. The textiles were made of worsted cotton yarn with linear density of 29.5 tex, with the Z type of twist, and the number of twists was 590 twists/1 m. The description of the parameters of textiles is given in Table 1. Table 1.

There were prepared two sets of square samples for two kinds of dimensions for the experiment: for device KES-FB2 size 20 cm × 20 cm and for device TH-7 size 5 cm × 5 cm. In every set (see Table 1) there were five types of fabrics, named S1–S5. In total 50 fabrics were prepared for the experiment. The fabrics were measured in the direction of the weft and warp on both devices. The values of bending force obtained on device TH-7 were converted to bending rigidity B [×10–4 Nm2/m] by means of the constant, as described above. The results underwent correlation analysis. The correlation coefficient for bending rigidity in the direction of the warp of the fabric reached value 0.94 and for the bending rigidity in the direction of weft of the fabric it reached value 0.98. Figure 9 contains results of compared bending rigidities for both devices. The correlation coefficient R for warp and weft equals a value of 0.97. Figure 9.
Comparison of values of bending rigidity measured on devices KES-FB2 and TH-7 for the warp and weft of fabrics from S1 to S5.

sec.title: Repeatability and reproducibility of measuring
sec.p: In the frame of verification of the correctness of results, repeated measurements were carried out (one operator measured one sample several times), as well reproduced measurements (two operators measured one sample). The variation coefficient for repeated and reproduced measurements was in the interval from 2 to 6%.

One experimenter measured five sets of samples from S1 to S5 on device TH-7. The measurement of any fabric was repeated three times. Table 2 illustrates the results of repeated measuring on the fabric type S1. The results show that the maximum variation coefficient 5.8% was obtained for the first measuring. sec.title: Square and circular shapes
sec.p: Device TH-7 was designed mainly for measuring circular samples with the diameter of 5 cm. However, the device can be also used for measuring square or rectangular samples, and even for measuring samples of other shapes, such as triangular or trapezium.

To examine the correctness of measuring of different shapes, we examined first the influence of the width of the sample on the final value of bending force or, more precisely, we compared the values of the square and rectangular shaped samples. The square samples were of size 5 cm × 5 cm and the rectangular ones were of size 2.5 cm × 5 cm.

The width of the rectangular shaped samples was half of the width of the square samples and that is why the value of the bending force of the rectangular samples should be approaching half of the value of the bending force measured on the square samples. The results are given in Table 5. The results showed that the bending force of rectangle samples reaches the anticipated half values of the bending force of square samples. The converted bending force for unit width is the same for both shapes of sample, for example, for the warp it is 0.12 Nm. The variation coefficient of measurement of the rectangular samples is, however, higher than of the square samples: it reaches values between 6 and 8%. Table 5.

sec.title: Measuring of bending rigidity of textiles in different directions
sec.p: This section will focus on a detailed description of the method of measuring the anisotropy of bending behavior of the fabric or, more precisely, on measuring the bending rigidity of textiles in different directions on circular samples. Firstly, however, the anisotropy was measured in the standard way, that is, on square samples in different directions.

The square samples were cut for eight different directions of turning in relation to the main direction of the warp threads: 0°, 22.5°, 45°, 67.5° and 90–157.5°, as can be seen from the cutting plan in Figure 11. The consumption of material for square and rectangular samples compared to circular ones is high. Due to the high consumption of material and time demands, some experimenters used a simpler method: they measured the anisotropy of bending rigidity only from 0° to 90° turning (one quadrant) and the obtained data were then copied according to the symmetry to the remaining quadrants of turning. However, the textile is of a very non-homogenous structure and the newly designed method of circular samples gives a more exact depiction of the bending behavior of the textile in different directions. Figure 11.
Scheme of cutting: (a) rectangular samples dimensions 2 cm × 9 cm for multidirectional fabric bending; (b) scheme of cutting circular and square samples diameter; (c) scheme of cutting square samples.

In our experiments we examined the bending behavior of the textile, this time in different directions, on square samples on devices TH-7 and KES-FB2. The final results were again tested by correlation analysis. The result is illustrated in Figure 12, where R = 0.99. Figure 12.
Anisotropy of bending rigidity B: comparison of results on device KES-FH2 and device TH-7.

The final values of the anisotropy of bending rigidity of square samples, obtained by measuring on devices KES-FB2 and TH-7, were also plotted in polar diagrams (see Figure 13). Figure 13.
Anisotropy of bending rigidity B [× 10–4 Nm2/m] square samples on devices KES-FB2 and TH-7.

As the final values of the anisotropy of bending behavior of square samples of fabrics (for device KES-FB2) correlated, it was possible to carry out experiments with circular samples only on device TH-7. The constant κ which is used for converting the bending force to bending rigidity is higher for the circular sample than for the square sample.

For the comparison of results, we used the former final results of the anisotropy of bending rigidity measured on square samples on device TH-7. After that, we measured five newly cut circular samples. They were measured in eight desired directions of turning. The values of the anisotropy of bending rigidity of square and circular samples were plotted in the polar diagram (Figure 14). The values of the anisotropy of bending behavior on square and circular samples underwent correlation analysis. The correlation coefficient was R = 0.98, as can be seen in Figure 15. Figure 14.
Anisotropy of bending rigidity B [× 10–4 Nm2/m] circular and square samples measured on device TH-7.
Figure 15.
Anisotropy of bending rigidity, comparison of results on square and circular samples on device TH-7.

The experiments have proved that it is possible to measure effectively the anisotropy of bending rigidity on circular samples. The newly used method, measuring circular samples on device TH-7, provides a more realistic image of the anisotropic behavior of textiles. Using circular samples for measuring the anisotropy of bending makes it possible to save a significant amount of material. If we want to calculate the anisotropy of bending force for eight directions of turning in relation to the warp, and each turning for five values, then for the circular samples it will be sufficient to cut only five samples and on them measure eight directions. Nevertheless, for square shaped samples it is necessary to cut 8 × 5 samples, because there has to be one sample for every turning, or rather 4 × 5 samples (on square samples two directions can be measured at the same time).

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: The aim of the presented article is to introduce a new way of measuring the anisotropy of bending rigidity on circular samples by means of the innovated device TH-7. The method of measuring on device HT-7 has been described here in detail. The results of the carried out analyses, which were intended to verify whether the method of measuring was correct, were presented. The results have proved that the suggested method for measuring the anisotropy of bending rigidity on circular samples is convenient. The correlation coefficients of all comparisons were in the region of 0.9.

The method of measuring the anisotropy of bending rigidity was developed for studying the influence of the structure of material on the bending rigidity of the textile in different directions. Subsequently, it can be employed for the construction of textiles. The achieved values of the anisotropy of bending rigidity will also help further thorough research of draping and wrinkling behavior of textiles.
